3-electives-health-and-pe-nutrition-fitn.title: Nutrition, Fitness, and Safety for Grade 3
3-electives-health-and-pe-nutrition-fitn.subject: Health & PE

questions.prompt: Which food group helps your muscles grow strong?
questions.explanation: Proteins build and repair muscles, bones, and tissues. Good sources include chicken, fish, beans, and nuts.

questions.prompt: What does physical activity do for your body?

options.text: Makes your heart stronger, builds muscles, and improves mood
Only matters if you want to be an athlete

questions.explanation: Exercise benefits your whole body: stronger heart, healthier weight, better mood, improved focus, and better sleep.

questions.prompt: What should you do before crossing the street?
questions.explanation: Look both ways (left, right, left), wait for a walk signal, and cross quickly in a straight line.

questions.prompt: Which is a safe way to use playground equipment?

options.text: Follow rules, take turns, and don't push others
Run and push to get ahead
Use equipment the wrong way to be cool

questions.explanation: Following safety rules prevents injuries. Taking turns, following directions, and respecting others keeps everyone safe.

questions.prompt: What are the five food groups?
questions.explanation: Fruits, vegetables, grains, protein, and dairy. A healthy diet includes foods from all five groups.

questions.prompt: How much physical activity should kids your age get each day?

options.text: At least 60 minutes of activity (can be broken into smaller chunks)
As much as possible without breaks

questions.explanation: Kids should aim for 60+ minutes daily of moderate activity like walking, running, playing, or sports.

questions.prompt: Explain why wearing a helmet while biking is important.
questions.explanation: Helmets protect your head and brain from serious injury in case of falls or accidents.

questions.prompt: Which snack is the healthiest choice?
questions.explanation: Apples provide fiber and vitamins; peanut butter adds protein. Together they're filling and nutritious, unlike sugary/fried snacks.

4-electives-health-and-pe-nutrition-fitn.title: Nutrition, Fitness, and Safety for Grade 4
4-electives-health-and-pe-nutrition-fitn.subject: Health & PE

questions.prompt: What is a balanced meal?

options.text: Includes foods from multiple groups: grains, protein, vegetables, fruits, and dairy

questions.explanation: Balanced meals have variety. A plate with grilled chicken, brown rice, broccoli, and a side salad is balanced.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between a food's serving size and portion size?
questions.explanation: Serving size is what the label suggests; portion size is what you actually eat. They may be different.

questions.prompt: Why is stretching important before and after exercise?

options.text: It warms up muscles before activity and cools them down after, preventing injury

questions.explanation: Stretching increases flexibility, reduces soreness, and helps prevent pulls and strains.

questions.prompt: What should you do if you see someone being hurt or in danger?

options.text: Tell an adult or trusted authority immediately
Try to help yourself without telling anyone
Post about it on social media

questions.explanation: Adults are trained to handle emergencies safely. Telling them immediately is the safest action.

questions.prompt: How does water help your body?
questions.explanation: Water keeps you hydrated, helps digestion, keeps skin healthy, and helps your body work properly.

questions.prompt: What are the benefits of team sports?

options.text: Physical fitness, teamwork skills, and mental health benefits

questions.explanation: Team sports build fitness, teach cooperation, boost confidence, and create friendships.

questions.prompt: Describe three ways to stay safe while playing outdoors.
questions.explanation: Wear protective gear, follow safety rules, stay with friends, tell adults where you're going, and watch for traffic.

questions.prompt: Which habit promotes long-term health?

options.text: Regular physical activity combined with balanced eating
Eating junk food and being inactive

questions.explanation: Consistent healthy habits—daily activity and balanced meals—build health over time more than occasional efforts.

5-electives-health-and-pe-nutrition-fitn.title: Nutrition, Fitness, and Safety for Grade 5
5-electives-health-and-pe-nutrition-fitn.subject: Health & PE

questions.prompt: What are nutrients and why does your body need them?

options.text: Substances in food that help your body function, grow, and stay healthy (carbs, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals)

questions.explanation: Nutrients provide energy, build tissue, and regulate body functions. Different nutrients do different jobs.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between aerobic and anaerobic exercise?
questions.explanation: Aerobic (with oxygen): running, cycling—builds endurance. Anaerobic (without oxygen): sprinting, weight lifting—builds strength.

questions.prompt: How can you make a meal healthier?

options.text: Add vegetables, choose whole grains, limit added sugar, and use cooking methods like baking
Add more salt and fried foods

questions.explanation: Small changes like adding veggies, choosing whole grains, and cooking healthily improve nutrition without feeling deprived.

questions.prompt: What should you do in case of a minor cut or scrape?

options.text: Wash with soap and water, apply bandage if needed, tell an adult if it seems serious

questions.explanation: Cleaning wounds prevents infection. Bandaging protects them. Tell an adult if bleeding won't stop or signs of infection appear.

questions.prompt: Why is sleep important for your health and fitness?
questions.explanation: Sleep helps your body recover, repairs muscles, improves focus, strengthens immunity, and regulates mood.

questions.prompt: What is flexibility and how does it help your body?

options.text: Range of motion in joints; helps prevent injury and improves movement quality

questions.explanation: Flexibility reduces injury risk, improves posture, decreases soreness, and helps in daily activities.

questions.prompt: Explain what food poisoning is and how you can prevent it.
questions.explanation: Illness from harmful bacteria in food. Prevent by: cooking meat properly, washing hands and foods, refrigerating promptly, and not eating expired food.

questions.prompt: How does cardio fitness help your heart?

options.text: Strengthens heart muscle so it pumps blood more efficiently, lowering resting heart rate

questions.explanation: A stronger heart works more efficiently, delivering oxygen better throughout your body.

6-electives-health-and-pe-body-systems-a.title: Body Systems and Health for Grade 6
6-electives-health-and-pe-body-systems-a.subject: Health & PE

questions.prompt: What are the major body systems and what do they do?

options.text: Circulatory (transport blood), respiratory (breathing), digestive (processing food), nervous (communication), skeletal (support)
Only the heart and lungs matter

questions.explanation: Body systems work together. Circulatory delivers oxygen from respiratory to all cells; digestive provides nutrients; nervous controls everything.

questions.prompt: What is the role of the skeletal system?
questions.explanation: Supports your body, protects organs, enables movement (with muscles), and produces blood cells in bone marrow.

questions.prompt: How does the digestive system break down food?

options.text: Mechanically (chewing) and chemically (acids and enzymes) into nutrients your body can absorb

questions.explanation: Digestion starts in your mouth with chewing and enzymes, continues in your stomach with acid, and absorbs nutrients in the small intestine.

questions.prompt: What is the circulatory system and what does it do?
questions.explanation: The heart, blood vessels, and blood work together to transport oxygen, nutrients, and waste throughout your body.

questions.prompt: How do your lungs help provide oxygen to your body?

options.text: You breathe in oxygen; lungs exchange it into blood; circulatory system carries it to all cells

questions.explanation: Respiration: air in lungs exchanges oxygen for carbon dioxide in blood; blood carries oxygen to cells; cells release CO2 to breathe out.

questions.prompt: What is the nervous system responsible for?

options.text: Receiving information, processing it, and sending signals to control movement and body functions

questions.explanation: Brain and nerves control movement, sensations, emotions, breathing, heartbeat, and all automatic functions.

questions.prompt: Explain how the muscular and skeletal systems work together for movement.
questions.explanation: Muscles attach to bones via tendons. When muscles contract, they pull bones, creating movement at joints.

questions.prompt: What habits support healthy body systems?

options.text: Regular exercise, balanced nutrition, adequate sleep, and stress management

questions.explanation: Healthy habits keep all systems functioning optimally. Exercise strengthens hearts, nutritious food fuels systems, sleep enables recovery.

questions.prompt: What is a SMART fitness goal?
questions.explanation: SMART: 'Run a mile in 10 minutes by end of semester' is specific and measurable; 'get fit' is not.

questions.prompt: What are the main components of fitness?
questions.explanation: Cardiovascular endurance (heart), muscular strength (power), muscular endurance (repeated effort), flexibility, and body composition.

questions.prompt: How do you know if you're exercising at the right intensity?

options.text: You can talk but not sing; heart rate elevated; slightly breathless

questions.explanation: Moderate intensity: breathing elevated but you can still talk. This builds fitness while avoiding injury.

questions.prompt: What is cross-training and why is it helpful?
questions.explanation: Doing different activities (running, swimming, cycling) prevents boredom, prevents repetitive injuries, and works different muscles.

questions.prompt: How often should you exercise per week?

options.text: At least 3-5 days of activity with rest days for recovery

questions.explanation: Regular activity with rest days allows your body to recover and adapt, preventing burnout and injury.

questions.prompt: What role does warm-up and cool-down play in fitness?

options.text: Warm-up prepares muscles; cool-down helps recovery and prevents soreness
Can be skipped to save time

questions.explanation: Warm-up increases blood flow and flexibility; cool-down gradually lowers heart rate and prevents dizziness.

questions.prompt: Design a simple weekly fitness plan that includes different activities and rest days.
questions.explanation: Example: Monday run, Tuesday yoga, Wednesday bike, Thursday rest, Friday swim, Saturday strength, Sunday active recovery.

questions.prompt: How do you progress in fitness safely?

options.text: Gradually increase duration or intensity by small amounts, listen to your body, avoid sudden big jumps
Do as much as possible immediately
Stop at the first sign of effort

questions.explanation: Progressive overload prevents injury. Small, steady increases allow adaptation and sustainable improvement.

7-electives-health-and-pe-body-systems-a.title: Body Systems and Health for Grade 7
7-electives-health-and-pe-body-systems-a.subject: Health & PE

questions.prompt: What is homeostasis and why is it important?

options.text: Your body maintains stable internal conditions (temperature, pH, hydration); keeps you alive and functioning

questions.explanation: Homeostasis: body constantly adjusts to maintain ~98.6°F, correct pH, hydration, oxygen levels, etc. Disruptions cause illness.

questions.prompt: How does the immune system protect you from disease?
questions.explanation: White blood cells identify and destroy harmful bacteria, viruses, and pathogens; lymph nodes filter waste; antibodies recognize invaders.

questions.prompt: What is the endocrine system and how does it control your body?

options.text: Glands that produce hormones to regulate growth, metabolism, mood, and body functions
Only your brain controls body function

questions.explanation: Hormones (from thyroid, pancreas, adrenal glands, etc.) regulate sleep, hunger, growth, mood, and metabolism.

questions.prompt: What is the relationship between the nervous and endocrine systems?
questions.explanation: Nervous system sends quick signals; endocrine system sends slower hormonal messages. Together they coordinate all body functions.

questions.prompt: How does physical activity strengthen your cardiovascular system?

options.text: Regular exercise strengthens heart muscle, improves circulation, and increases lung capacity
Your heart gets weaker with exercise

questions.explanation: Aerobic activity builds heart strength and efficiency, lowering resting heart rate and blood pressure.

questions.prompt: What is inflammation and when is it helpful vs. harmful?

options.text: Immune response causing swelling; helpful for injury/infection response, harmful if chronic

questions.explanation: Acute inflammation (after injury) aids healing. Chronic inflammation (ongoing) contributes to disease and should be managed.

questions.prompt: How do different nutrients support specific body functions?
questions.explanation: Carbs = energy; protein = growth/repair; fats = hormone production; vitamins = immunity/function; minerals = bone strength.

questions.prompt: What lifestyle factors most significantly impact long-term health?

options.text: Regular exercise, balanced nutrition, adequate sleep, stress management, and avoiding harmful substances

questions.explanation: While genetics matter, lifestyle choices significantly influence disease risk, longevity, and quality of life.

questions.prompt: What is periodization in training?

options.text: Varying training intensity and focus over time (macrocycles, mesocycles) to avoid plateaus and prevent injury
Doing the same thing every day

questions.explanation: Periodization cycles through phases: building base, increasing intensity, peaking, recovery. This prevents boredom and overtraining.

questions.prompt: What is overtraining and how do you prevent it?
questions.explanation: Exercising too much without adequate recovery causing fatigue, injury risk, mood changes. Prevent: adequate rest days, varied intensity, listen to your body.

questions.prompt: How do you assess your current fitness level?

options.text: Fitness tests (push-ups, mile run, flexibility test, resting heart rate) establish baseline for progress tracking

questions.explanation: Baseline assessments show your starting point and motivate you by demonstrating improvement over time.

questions.prompt: What is specificity in fitness training?
questions.explanation: Training specifically for your goal: want to run faster? Do sprints. Want strength? Do resistance training. General fitness? Mix all types.

questions.prompt: How do you modify workouts for different fitness levels?

options.text: Beginners: lower intensity/volume; Advanced: higher intensity, complex movements, greater volume

questions.explanation: Appropriate progressions prevent injury and keep everyone challenged and motivated.

questions.prompt: What role does recovery play in a fitness plan?

options.text: Essential; muscles repair during rest, building strength; prevents overtraining and injury

questions.explanation: During rest, muscle protein synthesis occurs and glycogen replenishes. Adequate recovery is when adaptation happens.

questions.prompt: Create a 4-week progressive fitness plan with warm-up, main workout, cool-down, and rest days.
questions.explanation: Week 1: baseline 3 workouts; Week 2: increase duration; Week 3: increase intensity; Week 4: deload/recovery. Include variety.

questions.prompt: How do you track fitness progress and adjust your plan?

options.text: Track workouts, metrics (time, reps, distance), reassess monthly, adjust based on progress and how you feel

questions.explanation: Tracking reveals progress and identifies what works. Regular assessment ensures your plan stays effective and matched to current level.

8-electives-health-and-pe-body-systems-a.title: Body Systems and Health for Grade 8
8-electives-health-and-pe-body-systems-a.subject: Health & PE

questions.prompt: What are chronic diseases and what factors increase your risk?

options.text: Long-term diseases (diabetes, heart disease, cancer); risk factors: poor diet, inactivity, smoking, stress

questions.explanation: Chronic diseases account for most deaths. Many risk factors are controllable: exercise, healthy eating, no smoking, stress management.

questions.prompt: How does the brain regulate your body's responses to stress?
questions.explanation: Brain releases stress hormones (adrenaline, cortisol); increases heart rate, breathing, and alertness (fight-or-flight); chronic stress damages health.

questions.prompt: What is metabolism and how do age, genetics, and activity affect it?

options.text: Chemical processes producing energy; genetics determine baseline, but activity and muscle mass increase it significantly
Metabolism is the same for everyone

questions.explanation: Building muscle and exercising regularly increases metabolic rate. Age and hormones also influence it.

questions.prompt: How do different organ systems communicate and coordinate?
questions.explanation: Nervous system (quick signals), endocrine system (hormones), and circulatory system (transport) interconnect, enabling coordinated responses.

questions.prompt: What is the relationship between sleep and physical health?

options.text: Sleep is essential: immune function, memory consolidation, hormone regulation, muscle repair, weight management
Sleep is a waste of time
Quality doesn't matter; any sleep is the same

questions.explanation: Sleep deprivation impairs immunity, increases disease risk, affects mood, and harms cognitive function.

questions.prompt: How can inflammation affect your health long-term?

options.text: Chronic inflammation increases risk of heart disease, diabetes, arthritis, and cancer; managed by healthy lifestyle

questions.explanation: Anti-inflammatory diet (fruits, vegetables, fish), exercise, and stress management reduce chronic inflammation risk.

questions.prompt: Explain how lifestyle choices in your teenage years impact your long-term health.
questions.explanation: Habits formed now (exercise, nutrition, sleep, stress management) predict adult health outcomes. Bone density peaks in teens; muscle built now helps later.

questions.prompt: What strategies help maintain physical and mental health?

options.text: Regular exercise, balanced nutrition, adequate sleep, social connection, stress management, purposeful activities

questions.explanation: Holistic health requires attention to physical, mental, social, and emotional aspects of well-being.

questions.prompt: How do genetics and environment interact in fitness?

options.text: Genetics set potential; environment/training determines outcomes; both matter significantly
Environment matters completely regardless of genetics

questions.explanation: Genetic potential varies, but training, nutrition, sleep, and consistency determine actual fitness outcomes.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between training for endurance vs. strength?
questions.explanation: Endurance: aerobic activities (running, cycling) with moderate intensity, high volume; Strength: resistance training with heavy load, lower reps.

questions.prompt: How should you adjust your fitness plan as you get older?

options.text: Prioritize diverse activities, injury prevention, recovery, and adjust intensity based on goals and age
Always increase intensity regardless of age

questions.explanation: Teens can tolerate more training; adults need more recovery. Older people need flexibility and fall prevention but same activity principles apply.

questions.prompt: What role does nutrition play in a fitness plan?

options.text: Critical; provides energy, builds muscle, aids recovery; without proper nutrition, training efforts are limited
Nutrition doesn't matter if you exercise
Only elite athletes need good nutrition

questions.explanation: Nutrients fuel workouts, rebuild muscle, and enable adaptation. Poor nutrition limits fitness gains regardless of training quality.

questions.prompt: How do you create a sustainable long-term fitness habit?
questions.explanation: Start small, find activities you enjoy, set realistic goals, track progress, vary workouts, build social support, make it routine.

questions.prompt: What is the relationship between fitness, mental health, and resilience?

options.text: Regular exercise improves mood, reduces anxiety/depression, builds confidence, and develops resilience to stress
Mental health and exercise are unrelated
One has no impact on the other

questions.explanation: Exercise releases endorphins, provides coping mechanism for stress, builds confidence through achievement, and improves overall well-being.

questions.prompt: Design a comprehensive year-long fitness plan with periodization, progression, recovery, and assessment checkpoints.
questions.explanation: Include phases (base building, strength building, peak, recovery), monthly assessments, adjustments based on progress, and variety.

questions.prompt: How can you maintain fitness motivation over the long term?

options.text: Set evolving goals, track progress, vary activities, train with others, celebrate milestones, focus on how you feel

questions.explanation: Motivation requires intrinsic rewards (feeling good), extrinsic progress (visible improvement), and environmental support (community, variety).
